content: The Act may be cited as the "Recognizing Addiction as a Disease Act of 2007". The findings in the Act state that addiction is a chronic brain disease characterized by compulsive drug use despite harmful consequences. The term "abuse" increases stigma and shame, hindering individuals from seeking treatment. The Act highlights addiction as a chronic brain disease and emphasizes the need to remove stigma associated with the term "abuse." The National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, established in 1962, has made significant achievements in addressing health issues in children and mother-infant relationships. Its mission includes ensuring healthy births, protecting women during reproductive processes, and promoting the well-being of children for a disease-free and productive life. The National Institute of Child Health and Human Development has made unparalleled contributions to child health and human development, including reducing rates of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome, infant mortality, and maternal HIV transmission, developing the Hib vaccine, and training researchers who have greatly improved child health worldwide. Eunice Kennedy Shriver played a crucial role in establishing the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development in 1962, contributing significantly to child health worldwide.
